source.citation: Kosicki, J. & Dyson, S. 2004. Processing loaders show their advantage. FPInnovations Advantage Vol. 5 No. 6.
notes: Madill 3800 carrier + Waratah HTH624 danglehead processors working coastal BC clearcuts (Blocks B–D).
Block B = cold processing of loader-forwarded + grapple-yarded stems; Block C = hot processing of uphill yarded stems; Block D = mix of cold/hot yarded stems with low average piece size.

scenarios.name: loader_forwarded_cold
scenarios.description: Block B loader-forwarded stems processed from cold decks (May–July 2002).
notes: cold processing of long loader-forwarded decks allowed continuous grappling and minimal interaction delays.

scenarios.name: grapple_yarded_cold
scenarios.description: Block B grapple-yarded stems decked below the road (cold processing).
notes: Processing grapple-yarded stems was slower due to decking below road and repositioning effort.

scenarios.name: grapple_yarded_hot
scenarios.description: Block C uphill yarded stems processed hot (live deck) with occasional cold-loader forwarded top-ups.
notes: Hot processing benefited from balanced yarder/processor cycle and direct road placement for hot loading.

scenarios.name: grapple_yarded_low_volume
scenarios.description: Block D downhill yarded stems (mixed cold/hot) with small piece size (0.44 m³/stem).
notes: Lower productivity driven by short pieces placed below the road; mix of hot/cold processing with high travel.
